author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: What We Know About Iran’s Attack on Israel and What Happens Next
description: Israel is deciding how to respond to an attack by Tehran in which it fired hundreds of drones and missiles. Its allies are urging restraint.
content: World leaders are urging Israel to act with restraint after Iran launched a large aerial attack over the weekend, firing at least 300 drones and missiles. Israel’s war cabinet has not yet said how it will respond to the first such direct assault launched from Iranian territory after decades of shadow warfare between the two countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: Under Manfred Honeck, the Philharmonic Becomes One
description: In a program of Tchaikovsky and Rachmaninoff, a guest conductor coaxes a sumptuous sincerity from the orchestra’s musicians.
content: In a thrilling concert of Russian staples on Friday night, the conductor Manfred Honeck unified the players of the New York Philharmonic using something we don’t often hear from the stage of David Geffen Hall: a distinct point of view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Sununu Says Trump ‘Contributed’ to Insurrection, but Still Has His Support
description: The New Hampshire governor, who has been critical of the former president and supported Nikki Haley in the primary, said he wanted a Republican in the White House.
content: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire said on Sunday that former President Donald J. Trump “absolutely contributed” to an insurrection and that Mr. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election were “absolutely terrible” — but that nothing, not even felony convictions, would stop him from voting for Mr. Trump because the economy, border security and “culture change” were more important.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Spring Cleaning to Refresh; Bacon and Egg Don to Comfort
description: Eric Kim’s recipe combines soft scrambled eggs, crisped bacon and furikake-flecked rice for a fantastic breakfast-for-dinner dish.
content: Good morning. The birds are back in town, chirping at dawn, flitting to and from the feeders set up out back, firing up the cat at the window. There’s no languorous idyll in bed before breakfast these days; there’s much to be done. Daylight’s burning. Time for spring cleaning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Queer Women Behaving Badly: These Movies Scrap the Coming-Out Story
description: “Love Lies Bleeding,” “Bottoms” and “Drive-Away Dolls” are leading a wave of stories about lesbians living their lives, committing crimes along the way.
content: To a queer woman going to the movies, it may seem as if there has been something in the ether for the past year. First, in August, there was “Bottoms.” Then “Drive-Away Dolls” arrived in February. “Love Lies Bleeding” joined the fray in March. This cluster of relatively mainstream films about queer women, deliciously frothy and fun to watch, feels unprecedented.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Opened the Book App on My Tablet and Began Reading’
description: Bonding over Homer on the 1 train, giving a dashboard gift and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Can’t Keep it Together
description: Ryan Gosling hosted an episode that included appearances by Caitlin Clark, Emily Blunt and Kate McKinnon, another Ken song and multiple sketches full of people laughing at their own jokes.
content: If an entire Oscars ceremony full of Barbenheimer jokes and a killer Ryan Gosling performance of “I’m Just Ken” didn’t give you sufficient opportunity to say goodbye to the pop cultural phenomenon of “Barbie,” “Saturday Night Live” is here to make sure that you’ve had Kenough.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 14, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 14, 2024.
content: An article last Sunday about Bran­don Blackwell, who excelled on the British quiz show “University Chal­lenge,” misstated the name of the Los Angeles neighborhood where the College Bowl Company has its office. It is Woodland Hills, not Wild Hills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: A Portrait Fit for a Publisher
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr. steered The Times during an era of great change. His likeness now hangs at the organization’s headquarters.
content: A portrait of Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The New York Times from 1992 through 2017, was unveiled April 4 at The New York Times headquarters in Manhattan. The subject himself tugged a crushed velvet drape off the painting, by Katy Schneider, to applause from several dozen guests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Cacouris
title: Undergarments for the Ultrawealthy
description: Cadolle, a maker of corsets favored by designers like John Galliano and labels like Dior, is known for custom underpinnings that can cost thousands of dollars.
content: In a subterranean workroom of a building on Rue Saint-Honoré in Paris, there are cabinets filled with bags of Chantilly lace in myriad shades: Yves Klein blue, sherbet orange, a silvery periwinkle. Nestled between the furniture are some half-dozen sewing machines, at which a small staff of seamstresses works while constructing corsets for Cadolle, a company that has been making custom lingerie for almost 140 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: An Unexpected Player in Israel’s Defense: Jordan, Home to Many Palestinians
description: The Arab kingdom said it took military action to defend its territory against Iranian drone and missile strikes. Critics assailed the country as having helped defend Israel.
content: The response by Israel and other nations to Iran’s aerial attack kept the majority of its drones and missiles from landing in Israel, ensuring they caused only light damage and a handful of injuries, Israeli officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Monday Briefing: Israel Weighs a Response to Iran
description: Also, the Australian authorities are searching for a motive in the deadly stabbing attack.
content: Calm mostly prevailed in Israel yesterday after Iran fired more than 300 missiles and drones at the country overnight. Nearly all were intercepted, Israeli military officials said, and those that made an impact caused only minor damage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Brightly Colored Rock
description: Amanda Winters makes her New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich, Maggie Haberman and William K. Rashbaum
title: As Trial Looms, Trump Plays to a Jury of Millions
description: Donald J. Trump and his lawyers realize his chances in the courtroom are dicey. He intends to make whatever happens a political triumph.
content: The first criminal trial of Donald J. Trump will begin on Monday, and the 45th president thinks he can win — no matter what the jury decides. Mr. Trump will aim to spin any outcome to his benefit and, if convicted, to become the first felon to win the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Chang W. Lee
title: Should We Change Species to Save Them?
description: When traditional conservation fails, science is using “assisted evolution” to give vulnerable wildlife a chance.
content: For tens of millions of years, Australia has been a playground for evolution, and the land Down Under lays claim to some of the most remarkable creatures on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Johnson Says the House Will Vote on an Israel Bill in the Coming Days
description: Speaker Mike Johnson left unclear whether the vote on the security package, coming after Iranian attacks on Israel, would also include aid for Ukraine.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson said on Sunday after Iran’s overnight attack on Israel that the House would vote in the coming days on aid for Israel, and he suggested that aid for Ukraine could be included in the legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Iran Attack Tests Netanyahu’s Political Staying Power
description: In a deeply polarized country that has again come under attack, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s fate may depend on what happens next.
content: In a deeply divided Israel, even the dramatic scene above the country’s skies on Sunday is open to political interpretation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Iran Just Made a Big Mistake. Israel Shouldn’t Follow.
description: There now needs to be a large, sustained, global initiative to isolate Iran.
content: It would be easy to be dazzled by the way Israeli, American and other allied militaries shot down virtually every Iranian drone, cruise missile and ballistic missile launched at Israel on Saturday and conclude that Iran had made its point — retaliating for Israel’s allegedly killing a top Iranian commander operating against Israel from Syria — and now we can call it a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: He Was Blinded in One Eye, but Salman Rushdie’s Vision Is Undiminished
description: The author’s new memoir, “Knife,” addresses the attack that maimed him in 2022, and pays tribute to the wife who saw him through. “I wanted to write a book which was about both love and hatred — one overcoming the other,” he says.
content: Last May, nine months after the knife attack that nearly killed him, Salman Rushdie made a surprise appearance at the 2023 PEN America literary gala. His voice was weak and he was noticeably thinner than usual; one of his eyeglass lenses was blacked out, because his right eye had been blinded in the assault. But anyone wondering whether the author was still his old exuberant self would have been immediately reassured by the way he began his remarks, with a racy impromptu joke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: In Final Rally Before New York Trial, Trump Again Casts Himself as Political Victim
description: Campaigning in Pennsylvania on Saturday, Donald J. Trump once more falsely asserted that his criminal charges were an attempt by Democrats to keep him from the White House.
content: Two days before his first criminal trial was set to begin in Manhattan, former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday again framed the charges he faces as a broad attempt by Democrats to keep him from the White House, and he criticized a gag order placed on him by the judge in the New York case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carson Griffith
title: Prince Harry Hits the Polo Field in Front of Netflix Cameras
description: The Duke of Sussex competed in a match in South Florida the day after the announcement that he will be working on a new polo-related Netflix project.
content: In front of rolling cameras and a crowd of nearly 300 guests, Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, barreled toward one end of a polo field in South Florida on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: S’mores Kits? Saunas? Short-Term Rental Hosts Scramble to Stand Out.
description: More hosts are fighting over guests, driving down prices and forcing the hosts to find creative ways to entice renters.
content: In Scottsdale, Ariz., where the sunny weather lures bachelorette party revelers year-round, short-term rental owners are ready and waiting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: As Trump Ponders V.P. Contenders, He Asks: Can They Help Me Raise Cash?
description: Donald Trump’s concerns about money may have entered his vice-presidential calculations, along with political considerations and which contenders he likes the look of.
content: As former President Donald J. Trump sifts through potential running mates, he has peppered some advisers and associates with a direct question: Which Republican could best help him raise money for the rest of the presidential campaign?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Jan. 6 Obstruction Case at Supreme Court Could Help Trump and Many Others
description: The justices will hear arguments on Tuesday in a case that could alter hundreds of prosecutions for the assault on the Capitol and help define its meaning.
content: At first blush, the case the Supreme Court will hear on Tuesday seems technical, requiring the justices to parse a decades-old statute mainly concerned with the destruction of business records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca J. Ritzel
title: Lincoln’s Murder Is Often Re-enacted, but Not at Ford’s Theater
description: The theater says that allowing the assassination to be recreated there would undermine the gravity and significance of Abraham Lincoln’s death.
content: Since Ford’s Theater reopened as an active theater in 1968, it has rarely been the scene of a dramatic re-enactment of Abraham Lincoln being shot to death there on April 14, 1865.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer, Joseph Bernstein and Scott McIntyre
title: Dana White, Donald Trump and the Rise of Cage-Match Politics
description: White, chief executive of the bloody and beloved Ultimate Fighting Championship, has shot to the peak of Trump-era culture and political influence. What does he want?
content: Dana White’s diplomatic ambitions were clear, if complicated: Un-cancel Bud Light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: Israel Faced a Sophisticated Attack From Iran
description: The weapons Iran employed this weekend travel farther and are more precise than those Hamas and other allies have used against Israel in the past six months.
content: Late Saturday, Iran began firing hundreds of drones and missiles at Israel, including weapons that experts say are more sophisticated than anything Israel had encountered until now in six months of fighting with Hamas and its allies in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Natan Odenheimer
title: A 7-Year-Old Girl Is the Lone Serious Casualty of Iran’s Barrage
description: The girl, who lives in a Negev desert community that is home to Arab Bedouins, was clinging to life in a hospital after the attack.
content: The hospital waiting room was quiet on Sunday: There was no crowd of relatives, no flood of patients. Israel’s air defenses had just fended off a large-scale Iranian attack, with only one serious casualty recorded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 308
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lachlan Cartwright, David Linski, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, Anna Diamond, John Woo, Corey Schreppel and Steven Szczesniak
title: The Sunday Read: ‘What I Saw Working at The National Enquirer During Donald Trump’s Rise’
description: Inside the notorious “catch and kill” campaign that now stands at the heart of the former president’s legal trial.
content: At the center of the criminal case against former President Donald Trump in Manhattan is the accusation that Trump took part in a scheme to turn The National Enquirer and its sister publications into an arm of his 2016 presidential campaign. The documents detailed three “hush money” payments made to a series of individuals to guarantee their silence about potentially damaging stories in the months before the election. Because this was done with the goal of helping his election chances, the case implied, these payments amounted to a form of illegal, undisclosed campaign spending. And because Trump created paperwork to make the payments seem like regular legal expenses, that amounted to a criminal effort at a coverup, argued Alvin Bragg, the district attorney of Manhattan. Trump has denied the charges against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: For Caleb Carr, Salvation Arrived on Little Cat’s Feet
description: As he struggled with writing and illness, the “Alienist” author found comfort in the feline companions he recalls in a new memoir, “My Beloved Monster.”
content: J. Alfred Prufrock measured his life out in coffee spoons. Caleb Carr has done so in cats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Raquel Minian
title: Immigrant Detention Should Have No Place in Our Society
description: The nation’s detention and prison systems have grown side by side, buttressed by the same logic and practice.
content: In May 2018, Fernando Arredondo and his 12-year-old daughter, Andrea, reached the U.S.-Mexico border. The two had fled Guatemala after gang members killed his son, Marco, and threatened the rest of the family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Seeks to Head Off Escalation After Israel’s Successful Defense
description: The president told Israel that the interception of nearly all of the Iranian drones and missiles used to attack it constituted a major victory, and so further retaliation might not be necessary, U.S. officials said.
content: President Biden and his team, hoping to avoid further escalation leading to a wider war in the Middle East, are advising Israel that its successful defense against Iranian airstrikes constituted a major strategic victory that might not require another round of retaliation, U.S. officials said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Doug Mills and Alan Blinder
title: At the Masters, Champions Past, Present and Future
description: Golf enthusiasts regard a trip to the Masters Tournament as the stuff of dreams. Here are photos from this year’s tournament.
content: Seventy-five years ago this past week, Sam Snead won the Masters Tournament and became the first champion to receive one of Augusta National Golf Club’s green jackets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ismail Alfa and Ruth Maclean
title: She Was Kidnapped a Decade Ago With 275 Girls. Finally, She Escaped.
description: Their capture set off a global campaign to “Bring Back Our Girls.” But many are still missing, and kidnappings in Nigeria have proliferated.
content: Saratu Dauda had been kidnapped. It was 2014, she was 16, and she was in a truck packed with her classmates heading into the bush in northeastern Nigeria, a member of the terrorist group Boko Haram at the wheel. The girls’ boarding school in Chibok, miles behind them, had been set on fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Ameera Harouda
title: Palestinians Trying to Return to Northern Gaza Say Israeli Troops Fired on Them
description: An emergency worker and two people who tried to make the journey said Israeli troops shot into the crowd, forcing people to turn back in panic.
content: As thousands of displaced Palestinians tried to return to their homes in northern Gaza on Sunday, Israeli troops shot into the crowd, forcing people to turn back in panic, according to an emergency worker and two people who tried to make the journey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: Why Heat Pumps Are the Future, and How Your Home Could Use One
description: The highly efficient devices are the darlings of the environmental movement. Here’s why.
content: Heat pumps, which both warm and cool buildings and are powered by electricity, have been touted as the answer to curbing greenhouse gas emissions produced by homes, businesses and office buildings, which are responsible for about one-third of the emissions in New York State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: For Israel, Revenge Should Be a Dish Served Cold
description: Israel has the right to retaliate against Iran’s missile barrage. It should bide its time.
content: After several days during which Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei repeatedly vowed that “the evil Zionist regime” would be punished for its April 1 attack on Iran’s embassy complex in Damascus that killed seven Iranian military advisers, including three top commanders, the Islamic Republic struck. More than 300 drones and missiles launched from Iranian soil took aim at Israel on Saturday. Nearly all of them were intercepted, mainly by Israeli or American defenses, with a report of just one Israeli casualty, a girl from a Bedouin community wounded by shrapnel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Netflix’s New Film Strategy: More About the Audience, Less About Auteurs
description: Dan Lin, the streaming service’s new film chief, wants to produce a more varied slate of movies to better appeal to the array of interests among subscribers.
content: Back in, say, 2019, if a filmmaker signed a deal with Netflix, it meant that he or she would be well paid and receive complete creative freedom. Theatrical release? Not so much. Still, the paycheck and the latitude — and the potential to reach the streaming service’s huge subscriber base — helped compensate for the lack of hoopla that comes when a traditional studio opens a film in multiplexes around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta and Emma Bubola
title: U.S. Intercepts Dozens of Iranian Drones and Missiles Aimed at Israel
description: Britain’s defense secretary said British jets were prepared to intercept Iranian attacks. France and Germany expressed support.
content: The U.S. military said that it had shot down dozens of the drones and missiles that Iran fired at Israel on Saturday, a strong demonstration that despite recent criticism of Israel’s conduct of the war in Gaza, Washington was firmly committed to protecting a key ally from Iran, a mutual adversary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Ruth Igielnik
title: Four Years Out, Some Voters Look Back at Trump’s Presidency More Positively
description: A new poll by The New York Times and Siena College finds that voters think highly of the former president’s record on the economy, but memories of his divisiveness largely remain intact.
content: Views of Donald J. Trump’s presidency have become more positive since he left office, bolstering his case for election and posing a risk to President Biden’s strategy of casting his opponent as unfit for the presidency, according to a new poll by The New York Times and Siena College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: At Milan Design Week, a Smorgasbord of Tables and Table Toppers
description: The annual festival of furnishings and household objects features a variety of items that can be turned into tables.
content: At Alcova, an annual Milan Design Week exhibition that celebrates the unconventional, an aptly named San Francisco studio named Surfacedesign is showing tables and other furniture pieces made from boulders. There is no end to the movable feast of materials that can be turned into tables, just as there is no end to the things you can put on them. The seemingly infinite options are further amplified by an urge to give new life to old, overlooked or discarded stuff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Strikes Upend Israel’s Belief About Iran’s Willingness to Fight It Directly
description: Israel had grown used to targeting Iranian officials without head-on retaliation from Iran, an assumption overturned by Iran’s attacks on Saturday.
content: Iran’s unprecedented strikes on Israel this weekend have shaken Israel’s assumptions about its foe, undermining its long-held calculation that Iran would be best deterred by greater Israeli aggression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran’s Strikes on Israel Open a Dangerous New Chapter for Old Rivals
description: Experts say Tehran does not want a broader war. But it is far from clear whether Iran or Israel will choose to escalate a conflict that has become more direct and out of the shadows.
content: Iran has retaliated directly against Israel for the killings of its senior generals in Damascus, Syria, with an onslaught of more than 300 drones and missiles aimed at restoring its credibility and deterrence, officials and analysts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: The Dystopian ‘Civil War’ Reaches No. 1 at the Box Office
description: Alex Garland’s movie, starring Kirsten Dunst, surpassed “Godzilla x Kong,” with an estimated $25.7 million in North American ticket sales on its first weekend.
content: Hollywood executives — not all, but most — have insisted for years that uncomfortable, thought-provoking, original movies can no longer attract big audiences at the box office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: News Outlets Urge Trump and Biden to Commit to Presidential Debates
description: In an unusual statement, the news organizations said “there is simply no substitute” for a face-to-face debate, a campaign staple since 1976.
content: A group of major news organizations — including The Associated Press and the five big broadcast and cable networks — issued an unusual joint statement on Sunday urging President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump to commit to participating in televised debates before Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Stormy Daniels and the Comeuppance of Donald Trump
description: Trump has long treated women as objects, targets, supplicants. I suspect he never thought they would be the ones to hold him accountable.
content: Sometimes I lie awake at night wondering whether Donald Trump is afraid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter May
title: The Most Famous Golfer at the Masters Is Black. Why Aren’t There More Players Like Him?
description: Tiger Woods said he owes his career to Charlie Sifford, the first Black member of the P.G.A. But the golf world has done far too little to promote Black players.
content: When the Masters Tournament commenced on Thursday, featuring 89 competitors, there was exactly one Black golfer in the field: the one we all know, Tiger Woods. Beyond that, the field for the 88th Masters didn’t look all that different from the previous 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Rico Wade, an Architect of Atlanta Hip-Hop, Dies at 52
description: As one-third of the production team Organized Noize, he nurtured the careers of Outkast, Goodie Mob and Future from the confines of his mother’s basement, known as the Dungeon.
content: Rico Wade, an architect of Southern hip-hop who produced albums for rap acts including Outkast, Goodie Mob and Future, has died. He was 52.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meher Ahmad
title: Do You Have a Family Story That Defines Who You Are?
description: History isn’t just learned through textbooks; everybody has a story, big or small, that tells us about America.
content: American history is often recounted through major events. But every family has its own stories, moments that were perhaps never recorded in a history book — the purchase of a home, a hometown disaster, a death, a move — yet speak to the events that define the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: At Carnegie Hall, Weimar Is Irresistible but Vaguely Defined
description: Carnegie’s intermittently illuminating festival “Fall of the Weimar Republic” has suffered from interjections of too much standard repertory.
content: In the middle of Erich Wolfgang Korngold’s suite of incidental music for “Much Ado About Nothing,” there’s a march meant to accompany Dogberry, Shakespeare’s comic constable, and his fellow watchmen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 15, 2024
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Yan Zhuang
title: After Stabbing Rampage, Australia Struggles With How and Why
description: The police have yet to determine a motive for Saturday’s attack, which left six people dead, but said the assailant had mental-health problems.
content: On a perfect mid-autumn day, the scene at an upscale suburban mall in Sydney, Australia, was as humdrum as it was idyllic: mothers pushing strollers, gaggles of teenagers being young, families whiling away the weekend afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather and Todd Heisler
title: American Pizazz Meets the Staid Traditions of Sumo
description: At Madison Square Garden, New Yorkers got a rare look at an ancient Japanese sport, cheering and booing as though they were watching a Yankees game.
content: Two giant, shirtless men bow respectfully and then hurl themselves at each other in a violent pas de deux that ends with a victory in seconds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: What Happened to Damages That O.J. Simpson Owed to the Victims’ Families?
description: In 1997, a jury in a civil trial awarded the families of Ronald Goldman and Nicole Brown Simpson $33 million. Today, the amount still owed has more than tripled.
content: More than 25 years ago, O.J. Simpson was found liable in civil court for the deaths of his ex-wife Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman, her friend, and was ordered to pay more than $33 million to their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Atmosphere of the ‘Manosphere’ Is Toxic
description: Struggling men need to leave the gurus behind.
content: To understand the state of men in this country, it’s necessary to know three things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: What Weapons Did Israel Use to Block Iran’s Attack?
description: Israel’s Iron Dome defense system intercepts rockets that fly in high arcs, while its Arrow 3 system can stop ballistic missiles outside the atmosphere.
content: Israeli forces used two main defensive weapons, the Iron Dome and the Arrow 3, to shoot down most of the more than 300 drones, ballistic missiles and cruise missiles fired at its territory by Iran, while others were shot down by the United States and other allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Iredale
title: Fashion’s Favorite Farm
description: What is Sky High Farm? A brand? An art project? A business? A charity? It wants to be all of the above.
content: There are certain things the fashion industry will always love: The young and beautiful. Art and money. Nostalgia. A comeback. From time to time, it also loves to throw itself behind a cause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning
title: Iran Attacks Israel
description: What we know about the assault — and what it means.
content: Iran’s missile attack on Israel has ended, for now, and virtually none of the missiles reached their targets.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Thousands Try to Run, or Swim Across ‘Death River,’ to Dodge the Draft
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 14, 2024.
content: “Everybody is afraid to die, but we try to make them look at it from a different perspective.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: This Prosecutor Pledged to Change George Floyd’s City. Her Critics Are Circling.
description: Mary Moriarty, a former chief public defender, became the top prosecutor in Minneapolis, promising an overhaul. Now she faces criticism, including from fellow Democrats.
content: Mary Moriarty, a former public defender, became Minneapolis’s top prosecutor last year after persuading voters shaken by the murder of George Floyd that she could improve public safety by reining in police misconduct and making the criminal justice system less punitive.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Beautiful World of Birding
description: Readers discuss the hobby’s many benefits. Also: Friends in the court; politicians’ health; testing the candidates; banning plastic foam.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Iran’s Attacks Bring Long Shadow War With Israel Into the Open
description: The volley of drones and missiles was the first time that Tehran directly attacked Israel from its own territory, one expert said.
content: For decades, Israel and Iran have fought a shadow war across the Middle East, trading attacks by land, sea, air and in cyberspace. The barrage of drones and missiles Iran launched at Israel on Saturday — though nearly all were shot down or intercepted — represented a watershed in the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Caitlin O'Hara
title: How Women at One Arizona Clinic Are Grappling With the Abortion Ruling
description: Inside Acacia Women’s Center, patients described a mix of fear, anger and anxiety after the State Supreme Court’s decision to reinstate a law that bans nearly all abortions.
content: Leah found out she was five weeks pregnant on the same day that the Arizona Supreme Court upheld an 1864 law banning nearly all abortions in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: ‘Sunset Boulevard,’ Heading to Broadway, Wins Big at Olivier Awards
description: The musical, which stars Nicole Scherzinger, won seven awards at Britain’s version of the Tonys. And Sarah Snook won best actress for “The Picture of Dorian Gray.”
content: A reimagining of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Sunset Boulevard,” starring Nicole Scherzinger as Norma Desmond, the long forgotten silent movie star who descends into madness, was the big winner at this year’s Olivier Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and AFP
title: Iran Launches Aerial Attack on Israel
description: Air-raid sirens sounded across Israel and the West Bank as the night sky lit up with incoming missiles and interceptions.
content: Air-raid sirens sounded across Israel and the West Bank as the night sky lit up with incoming missiles and interceptions.
source.name: The New York Times
